title: Pro Log: Men’s Giro kicks off; Women’s Vuelta; Egan Bernal’s new kit; Controversy at Liège-Bastogne-Liège Juniors; and Ineos’s new sponsor?
content:
Cyclist
Pro Log: Men’s Giro kicks off; Women’s Vuelta; Egan Bernal’s new kit; Controversy at Liège-Bastogne-Liège Juniors; and Ineos’s new sponsor?

Welcome back to another edition of Pro Log. Here’s a rundown of the latest results before we get started:

  • Giro d’Italia, Stage 3, Sun 12th May: 1st Mads Pedersen, Lidl-Trek, 3h 49min 47sec; 2nd Corbin Strong, Israel-Premier Tech, +00sec; 3rd Orluis Aular, Movistar, +00sec.
  • Tro-Bro Leon, Sun 12th May: 1st Bastien Tronchon, Decathlon-AG2R La Mondiale, 4h 43min 14sec; 2nd Pierre Gautherat, Decathlon-AG2R La Mondiale, +00sec; 3rd Valentin Madouas, Groupama-FDJ, +19sec.
  • Gent-Wevelgem, U23, Sun 11th May: 1st Alessandro Borgo, Bahrain Victorious DT, 4h 24min 44sec; 2nd Patrick Frydkjær, Lidl-Trek Future Racing, +00sec; 3rd Joshua Golliker, EF Education-Aevolo, +01sec.
  • La Vuelta Femenina, Overall, Sat 10th May: 1st Demi Vollering, FDJ-Suez, 19h 41min 32sec; 2nd Marlen Reusser, Movistar, +1min 01sec; 3rd Anna van der Breggen, SD Worx-Protime, +1min 16sec.
  • La Vuelta Femenina, Stage 7, Sat 10th May: 1st Demi Vollering, FDJ-Suez,4h 23min 34sec; 2nd Marlen Reusser, Movistar, +11sec; 3rd Anna van der Breggen, SD Worx-Protime, +25sec.

Mads Pedersen is back in pink

He wasn’t out of it for long. After winning the opening stage to claim the first maglia rosa of the race in Albania, Mads Pedersen ceded the lead in the Giro d’Italia to Primož Roglič in the Stage 2 time-trial. The TT was won by Josh Tarling but only one second separated Pedersen and Roglič in the overall standings after a big effort from the Dane. With a fast finish expected on Stage 3, the jersey looked set to change hands again.

Pedersen held on within the main group on the day’s climbs, with his Lidl-Trek team controlling it to perfection once again. Then it was just a matter of relying on his leadout train to deliver him to the finishing straight. With 150m to go Pedersen took over, resplendent in the ciclamino jersey, and held off stiff competition from Israel-Premier Tech’s Corbin Strong to win pink back for the first rest day.

As it stands, Pedersen leads the general classification by nine seconds ahead of Roglič, and he also tops the standings in the points classification, with some more sprinting opportunities to come over the next few days.

Demi Vollering wins first Grand Tour for FDJ-Suez

Demi Vollering won La Vuelta Femenina on the weekend by over a minute ahead of former teammates Marlen Reusser and Anna van der Breggen. With a solid lead in the maillot rojo from her solo victory on Stage 5’s summit finish, she only had to defend the jersey from attacks on the last day up to Alto de Cotobello in Asturias.

With the favourites group thinned down to four, Vollering kicked away from Reusser and Van der Breggen in the final kilometre, securing the first Grand Tour in FDJ-Suez’s 20-year history.

Cédrine Kerbaol also impressed with a much improved climbing performance taking her to fourth place overall. Also shining as per usual was Marianne Vos, who won two stages and breezed her way to the points jersey for the third consecutive year.

Egan Bernal shows off new Colombian kit

Colombian road race and time-trial champion Egan Bernal is sporting a new jersey at the Giro d’Italia. Inspired by the Café de Colombia team that ran from 1983 to 1990, the kit showcases similar yellow and blue triangles at the base while still keeping the Ineos Grenadiers red and black gradient on his left sleeve.

Ineos set for extra sponsorship

Speaking of Ineos Grenadiers, The Times reported last week that the squad is close to a multi-million-pound sponsorship deal with TotalEnergies, whose deal with the eponymous ProTeam comes to an end this year.

Junior Liège-Bastogne-Liège race finish ruined

A police motorbike crossed in front of Leander De Gendt (Cannibal-Victorious U19 DT) as he launched his sprint in the finale of the Liège-Bastogne-Liège junior race against Harry Hudson (Fensham Howes Junior RT) yesterday. Video clearly shows the motorbike cutting in front of both riders. De Gendt, on the right-hand side, was forced to move around the bike mid-sprint and thus lost the race.

After the finish, Cannibal Victorious team manager Francis Van Mechelen called for the race to be deemed a tie – to no avail.

Miguel Ángel López appeal rejected

The Court of Arbitration for Sport (CAS) has dismissed the appeal by Miguel Ángel López over his four-year ban for being found guilty of an anti-doping rule violation for use and possession of a prohibited substance prior to the 2022 Giro d’Italia.

Astana cut ties with the Colombian in December that same year following his alleged links to Marcos Maynar, who was under investigation for being part of a doping ring through ‘Operation Ilex’. López then raced for Team Medellín and won several lower tier races in South America.

With his appeal now rejected, his ban stands until 24th July 2027.

Lincoln Grand Prix results

A post shared by Rapha Lincoln Grand Prix (@lincolngrandprix)

James McKay (Wheelbase-CabTech-Castelli) won the 69th edition of the men’s Lincoln Grand Prix with its famed Michaelgate cobbled climb this weekend, just beating Alex Peters (DAS-Hutchinson) to the line after 167km. Lauren Dickson (Handsling-Alba Development RT) secured victory in the women’s race in a similarly close finish, seeing off Anna Morris (racing as a Private Member) after 103km.

The Lincoln Grand Prix marked the start of Rapha’s new Super-League, which awards points to accumulate a running total across the domestic calendar.
